2 Copula Theory According to Wikipedia, a copula is a multivariate cumulative distribution function for which the marginal probability distribution of each variable is uniform on the interval \([0, 1]\). Let \((X_1, X_2)\) be a bivariate random vector with continuous marginal distributions; this implies that the marginal cumulative distribution functions [CDFs] \(F_i(x_i) = P(X_i \le x_i)\) are continuous functions as well. By applying the probability integral transform, the random vector \((U_1, U_2) = (F(X_1), F(X_2))\) has marginals that are uniform on the interval \([0, 1]\): this corresponds to the definition of copula that was introduced above. Therefore, the copula \(C\) of \((X_1, X_2)\) is defined as the joint CDF of \((U_1, U_2)\): \[ C(u_1, u_2) = P(U_1 \le u_1, U_2 \le u_2) \] More formally, \(C: [0, 1]^d \rightarrow [0, 1]\) is a \(d-\)dimensional copula if \(C\) is a joint CDF of a \(d-\)dimensional vector on the unit (hyper-)cube \([0, 1]^d\) with uniform marginals.
